# Chord: 11th in C (Shape: E)

The 11th chord in C, with shape E, is a rich and colorful chord that adds depth and complexity to music. It is formed by stacking the 1st (C), 3rd (E), 5th (G), 7th (B), and 11th (F) notes of the C major scale. The shape of this chord on the guitar resembles an E major chord played in the open position, with the addition of the 11th (F) note on the top string.

## Notes and Intervals
- 1st (C): This is the root note of the chord and provides the foundation for the harmony.
- 3rd (E): The major third gives the chord its major quality.
- 5th (G): The perfect fifth provides stability and support to the chord.
- 7th (B): The major 7th adds tension and a jazzy flavor to the chord.
- 11th (F): The 11th note, an octave above the 4th, adds color and extension to the chord.

## Genre and Musical Flavor
The 11th chord in C, with the shape E, is commonly used in jazz, R&B, and funk music. It adds a sophisticated and jazzy flavor to chord progressions, creating a sense of tension and resolution. This chord is often used in more complex harmonic contexts to enhance the harmonic palette and create a lush sound.

## Songs
Here are three songs that feature the 11th chord in C (Shape: E) prominently:

1. "So What" by Miles Davis - This jazz classic features modal chord progressions that include 11th chords, creating a cool and atmospheric vibe.
   
2. "Redbone" by Childish Gambino - In this modern R&B hit, the 11th chord adds a soulful and funky quality to the chord progression, enhancing the groove of the song.
   
3. "Chameleon" by Herbie Hancock - This funk masterpiece utilizes 11th chords in a funky and syncopated groove, showcasing the versatility and hip sound of this chord.
